Trial_Design.evidence: In 2 small single-institution randomized clinical trials

Participants.evidence: first-year surgical (ESRT-1, 8 weekly, 2-hour classes, n = 44) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2, 6 weekly, 90-minute classes, n = 45) resident trainees

Intervention.evidence: ESRT, a tailored mindfulness-based cognitive training program, was administered and iteratively adapted

Objective.evidence: To determine the effects of ESRT (an iteratively adapted and tailored MBI) on perceived stress, executive cognitive function, psychosocial well-being (ie, burnout, mindfulness), and pro-inflammatory gene expression in surgical (ESRT-1) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2) PGY-1 volunteers.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary and secondary outcomes were, respectively, perceived stress and executive function.

Number_Randomised.evidence: n = 44) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2, 6 weekly, 90-minute classes, n = 45)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Neither version of ESRT appeared to affect perceived stress. Higher executive function and mindfulness scores were seen in ESRT-1, and lower emotional exhaustion and depersonalization scores in ESRT-2
